data.title: Debug Target drop-down too narrow

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 14380

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open .NET Core project
2. Hit View | Debug

Cannot see the full target name in the debug target drop-down:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/961950/16546788/dafffb32-410a-11e6-872b-c25e76b6d713.png)

Debug target field should be widened so the full debug target name can be displayed.

data.title: Ctrl+Shift+2 marks the editor as dirty even if no changes are made
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Win10 Home

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Select some lines that are already sorted alphabetically
2. Press Ctrl+Shift+2

The editor is marked as dirty, but nothing has changed.

data.title: Allow projects to suggest extensions
data.body:
It would nice if a project had a way to advertise what extensions are required or helpful within the context of a project. Perhaps a new file in the `.vscode` directory that allowed listing extensions and versions. For example:

``` json
{
    "typescript": "~1.8.0",
    "tslint": "~0.5.32"
}
```

This will help people that are just getting started on a project understand what dependencies are required to use the project.

When opening the project, VS Code might say something like, "This project has recommended extensions. Would you like to review them?"

data.title: Stop using sha256(MAC address) for telemetry machine ID
data.body:
Today, getMachineId [returns](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/b498c11bdfe92b1acec6b7957493f1f679088c2a/src/vs/platform/telemetry/node/machineId.ts#L12) the sha256 hash of the machine's (primary?) MAC address.

There are a few things wrong with this from a privacy perspective.
1. The MAC address is personally identifiable information. It allows Microsoft to identify a specific user's machine, even well after they've uninstalled Visual Studio Code, and can be easily correlated with other data sources.
2. Hashing does not anonymize. Microsoft can still look up a user by their MAC address.
3. MAC addresses are 48 bits, so the sha256 hash is relatively easily reversed to a unique value.

If VS Code wants to identify a given installation, the generally accepted method is to create a random value on first use and persist it.

It appears [other Microsoft developers](https://github.com/dotnet/cli/pull/3494) are relying on this worrying precedent, which makes it all the more important that this be fixed soon.

data.title: VSCode not to associate itself with any file type unless the user chooses so during installation
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: win10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install VSCode
2. Open `Control Panel > Control Panel Home > Default Programs > Assosiate a file type or protocol with a specific program`:  
   you'll notice that a hundred file types (in fact 101 !) are now associated with VSCode ([screenshot 1](https://i.imgur.com/ntouoyZ.jpg)).  
   There was no such option to opt in during the installation  ([screenshot 2](https://i.imgur.com/pZHEvn5.png))  
   neither there's a way to remove the file associations inside the program preferences.  
   The only way remove the file associations is to uninstall VSCode altogether.

For reference, all other editors that I have installed: Sublime Text, Atom, Notepad++,  gVim, UltraEdit 
don't associate themselves with any file type.

---

So, my suggestion: 
VSCode not to associate itself with any file extension unless the user chooses so during installation. 
Even better, to be able to configure file type associations with VSCode (enable/disable each one) , inside the program's preferences.

data.title: Add additional context to debug adapter `evaluateRequest` calls.
data.body:
`DebugProtocol.EvaluateArguments` includes the `context` which can be `hover`, `watch`, or `repl`, but it would be helpful to (optionally) include additional context. In particular, for Clojure, the namespace in which the code is being evaluated is pertinent. A brute force way of passing on useful context would be to pass the text of the document in which the code is being executed if it is executed from a selection inside an editor. 

A more general approach would be to let an extension register a context generator function that gets passed the editor (to determine the selected text) and returns the `EvaluateArguments` object to be passed to the debug adapter. In this way the generator could limit the contextual information to only what is required (like the enclosing namespace in the case of Clojure). This would also allow the generator to expend the selection to an enclosing form, etc.

data.title: [html] Don't mark quoted strings as links

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insider - OS Version: Windows 10 -- Sorry for the English, I used Google Translator -- Problems with `src = "' '" and href = "' '"` Can not find file. Example: `` When using single quotes within double quotes. Do not allow it to be considered link when something comes after the extension. Example: `` `` Similar as in Eclipse. ---Suggestion--- *I did not find these options in VSCode - Open in a new tab when you click this link, as currently happens when we use with ".html" - For when image, example: `` or `` have the option to choose whether you want to open with VSCode or my standard program. In Eclipse, do not open a ".html" that is within the same folder (not considered link), when you put the full path. If possible do VSCode accept the way complete and short.

data.title: Ability to change the number of items stored in the recently used list

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: Add a setting that would allow you to change the number of items stored in the `File -> Open Recent` recently used list in Visual Studio Code. By default it stores 10 folders and 10 files that you have recently used as seen in the source code [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/f58289fdaf309c3ee2c45c41bf2486bfe5af25af/src/vs/code/electron-main/menus.ts#L47).

data.title: "Alt Gr" (Alt ground) not working inside terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Home

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the terminal inside VS Code
2. Try to write a letter that is only accessible using the "Alt Gr" keyboard button.

In my case, the "/" is under the "Q" in my notebook keyboard. When I tried to write "/" inside the terminal using the "Alt Gr", it was not possible. Out of the terminal I could write it without problem.

data.title: Search is slow
data.body: Suddenly, search (and file name search) is behaving far more slowly than it used to. VSCode search was instant, now, it is just faster for me to go to to the sidebar which i dont want to do.

data.title: Emmet Wrap with Abreviation removes vertical bar character.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insider
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

  Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a HTML file and type something with a | character.
2. Select the code piece wich contains the character
3. Call the command Wrap With Abreviation

data.title: Add Selection To Previous Find Match
data.body:
![demo](http://ww2.sinaimg.cn/mw1024/534b48acgw1f5fujti8vwg20a0064q4b.gif)

The shortcut keys is <kbd>Ctrl/Cmd</kbd> + <kbd>Y</kbd>.

But I want to use <kbd>Ctrl/Cmd</kbd> + <kbd>E</kbd> will be better, because the E in the upper left of the D.

Now the shortcut keys have too many duplicates.

``` json
{ "key": "cmd+e",                 "command": "workbench.action.quickOpen" },
{ "key": "cmd+p",                 "command": "workbench.action.quickOpen" },
{ "key": "ctrl+tab",              "command": "workbench.action.quickOpenNavigateNext",
                                     "when": "inQuickOpen" },
{ "key": "cmd+e",                 "command": "workbench.action.quickOpenNavigateNext",
                                     "when": "inQuickOpen" },
{ "key": "cmd+p",                 "command": "workbench.action.quickOpenNavigateNext",
                                     "when": "inQuickOpen" },
```

data.title: Local Typescript to be used by default (minor issue)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11

Although "typescript.tsdk" works fine it would be logical to make workspace local typescript to be used instead of VS code own copy.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Remove all  typescript.tsdk overrides.
2. Open a workspace with typescript@next installed locally.
3. TS files has no TS version is present in the status line.
4. Add `"typescript.tsdk": "./node_modules/typescript/lib"` to the workspace settings.
5. Local TS is being used.

Thanks

data.title: Electron Helper in processes is very confusing for Electron projects
data.body:
Hi. I'm very confused with processes in Activity Monitor while working on Electron projects.
The "Electron Helper" are usually processes of unbuilt projects, and while debugging performance or related stuff, too confused with this because have both processes of VSCode and currently launched app (launched with prebuilt Electron).

After build, all processes are usually renamed to something like "My App Helper", but VSCode still has dummy names there - please, fix this.
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch VSCode
2. Check Activity Monitor

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1391015/16540727/36828f04-4077-11e6-91da-24692d3d1630.png)

data.title: I don't use Japanese IME on integrated terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10 th2

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Ctrl + `, Open integrated terminal. Set cursor on integrated terminal.
2. Alt + `, turn on IME.
3. I can't | ALT + ` should turn on IME | But it doesn't, I don't use Japanese IME on integrated terminal.

data.title: Exact matches in symbols fuzzy search are not on top
data.body:
I was a bit amazed by this, this is a screenshot from a file wide symbols listing (which should be quick to generate):

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/64731/16539812/ca2360d8-4056-11e6-8195-6025136180b4.png)

Why does it suggest me a "LoggedIn" as default, rather than "Login" which is exact match? I think fuzzy search sorting should be predictably ordered. Exact matches should be at the top, especially on quick commands like file wide symbols search.

Ordering, on top of my head, should be:

Exact matches,
Matches that begins with the word,
Fuzzy matches

Version 1.3.0 insider

data.title: DND color of tabs in light theme is not very visible
[API]: Access variable from vscode.previewHtml
terminal.external.windowsExec Cannot be changed to powershell
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. change in settings terminal.external.windowsExec from default "cmd" to "powershell"
2. debug a node.js app with "externalConsole": true in the launch.json
   result : it opens up the default cmd instead of powershell
   although the integrated terminal works fine when I try to launch powershell.

EDIT: when I try to open a new command prompt through ctrl shift c it opens powershell.
Is this behavior intended?

data.title: vscode.workspace.openTextDocument should open in the active editor
data.body:
If we have two editors open side by side, 
the method  _vscode.workspace.openTextDocument ()_ always open file in the left editor instead of the active editor.

It would also be nice to choose (optionnaly) to open in a new editor (like ctrl + click)

_VSCode Version: 1.2.1 / OS Version: Windows 10_

data.title: API: allow case insensitive find files via vscode.workspace.findFiles()

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
**Steps to Reproduce:**
a file with name "Unit.pas"

```
filename = 'unit';
vscode.workspace.findFiles('**/' + filename + '.*', '')
```

**Problem:** 
file *Unit.pas" will not be found, because the case doesn't match.
(Windows is a case-insensitive files system)

_VSCode Version: 1.2.1 / OS Version: Windows 10_

data.title: Update to Electron 1.x
data.body:
This comes with the following framework updates:
- **Electron** 0.37.6 => 1.2.6
- **Chrome** 49 => 51
- **V8** 49 => 51
- **node.js** 5.10 => 6.1.0
- **libuv** 1.8 => 1.9

**Changelog**: 
- Electron: https://github.com/electron/electron/releases
- node.js: https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md
- libuv: https://github.com/libuv/libuv/blob/v1.x/ChangeLog

data.title: code --uninstall-extension only uninstalls latest version
data.body:
If you have 5-6 versions installed, it requires running the command 5-6 times to actually remove the extension. 
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insiders
- OS Version:Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have multiple version of an extension installed
2. Run code --uninstall-extension extensionname
